107: <p>Set the <code>width</code> and set <code>margin-left</code> and <code>margin-right</code> to <code>auto</code>. That's <strong>for horizontal only</strong>, though. If you want both ways, you'd just do it both ways. Don't be afraid to experiment; it's not like you'll break anything.</p>
<p>It cannot be centered if you don't give it a width. Otherwise, it will take, by default, the whole horizontal space.</p>
108:
<p>You might also get this error if your gateway timeout is too short and the resource you are accessing takes longer to process than the timeout. This may be the case for complex database queries etc. Thus, the above error code can be disguishing this problem. Just check if the error code is 504 instead of 404 as in Kamils answer above or something else. If it is 504, then increasing the gateway timeout might fix the problem.</p>
<p>In my case the CORS error could be removed by disabling the same origin policy (CORS) in the IE browser, see <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/20947359/how-to-disable-same-origin-policy-internet-explorer">How to disable same origin policy Internet Explorer</a>. After doing this it was a pure 504 error in the log.</p>

<p>To resolve this issue write this line of code in your <code>doGet()</code> or <code>doPost()</code> function whichever you are using in backend.
<code>response.setHeader("Access-Control-Allow-Origin", "*");</code></p>
110:
<p>There is some method to the madness. As a general rule, if a browser can interpret a date as an ISO-8601, it will. "2005-07-08" falls into this camp, and so it is parsed as UTC. "Jul 8, 2005" cannot, and so it is parsed in the local time.</p>

<p>See <a href="http://blog.dygraphs.com/2012/03/javascript-and-dates-what-mess.html">JavaScript and Dates, What a Mess!</a> for more.</p>

<p>While <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/a/2587398">CMS is correct</a> that passing strings into the parse method is generally unsafe, the new <a href="http://www.ecma-international.org/publications/files/ECMA-ST/ECMA-262.pdf" rel="nofollow noreferrer">ECMA-262 5th Edition</a> (aka ES5) specification in section 15.9.4.2 suggests that <code>Date.parse()</code> actually should handle ISO-formatted dates.  The old specification made no such claim.  Of course, old browsers and some current browsers still do not provide this ES5 functionality.</p>

<p>Your second example isn't wrong.  It is the specified date in UTC, as implied by <code>Date.prototype.toISOString()</code>, but is represented in your local timezone.</p>
